Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Transport, Internal Waves and Mixing in the Samoan Passage
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:

The bulk of Antarctic Bottom Water flowing northward into the abyssal North Pacific goes through the Samoan Passage, making it a key choke point in the overturning circulation of the Pacific. Detailed current meter and hydrographic observations confirm a strong northward flow of 6.0 Sverdrups. In addition, measurements are suggestive of extremely strong mixing and hydraulic control. However, many important questions remain unanswered, including the degree of hydraulic control of the flow, the strength of the mixing and the processes leading to it, the role of tidal and near-inertial flows in modulating the flow and the mixing, and the temporal variability of the transport. A better understanding of each of these is vital to our understanding of the large-scale circulation in the Pacific, as well as to our general understanding of flow through deep passages.

This project entails a coordinated observational and modeling program to measure and understand flow and mixing through the Samoan Passage, which includes the following elements: 1) Two cruises, each including a 25-day focused mooring array with profiling instrumentation and a ship survey with lowered ADCP/CTD and microstructure profilers to resolve the currents and mixing in time and space. The cruises will be separated by 18 months to enable a long monitoring time-series and a sharper focus in the second cruise based on the analysis of data from the first. 2) An 18-month monitoring mooring array deployed between the cruises at the same location as that done 20 years prior in order to obtain another direct estimate of the properties and transport through the passage. 3) A hierarchy of models of differing complexity and realism, ranging from a 2-D MIT gcm configuration used for internal wave and exchange flow problems through regional 3-D runs to evaluate downstream overflow evolution, rotational effects and the influence of remote internal wave sources. Together, the models will bring a larger-scale context to the observations and allow testing of hypotheses and parameter dependencies. 4) Detailed multi-beam bathymetric mapping of the passage.

Broader Impacts:

The abyssal circulation is expected to influence the ocean's response to climate change and atmospheric carbon dioxide increases on the longest timescales, and the Samoan Passage is clearly a weak point in most large scale ocean models. This work directly addresses the processes that these models will need to simulate in order to improve their predictive capability. In addition, the community recognizes a need for extended monitoring of the Samoan Passage, in like manner to ongoing efforts in the Atlantic (Line W, RAPID), in order to assess decadal changes to the Pacific overturning circulation. The proposed measurements and modeling are intended to determine the most efficient configuration for such a monitoring array. A variety of outreach activities are planned in conjunction with the cruises, including documentary filming and exhibits at local science centers. The project will educate a postdoc and graduate student in the US, as well as 4 summer undergraduate fellows. In addition, the inclusion of Canadian and Australian scientists and students in the work will support international collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal activity of this project was a large physical oceanographic field experiment in the Samoan Passage--the primary gateway for dense Antarctic-origin bottom water to flow into the North Pacific (see Figure). Because of the scarcity of previous observations and the large volume (roughly 15% of the world's oceans) ventilated by this flow, climate system model improvements arising from this work have the potential to transform our ability to predict long-term climate change and its impacts (including warming and sea level rise).

The field observations included (1) a broad survey of the distribution of dense water transports and turbulence around the complex bathymetry of the Samoan Passage, (2) an 18-month timeseries of total transport, and (3) a detailed exploration of the processes responsible for mixing at particular sills and bathymetric features.

Our analysis of the 18-month timeseries (2012-2014) shows that warming of the dense overflow of about 0.02 degrees Celsius has occurred since the first Samoan Passage transport measurements 20 years earlier (1992-1994). In addition, the transport has decreased by about 10%, although the large variability at annual and monthly timescales makes it difficult to be certain that this is a long-term trend. Both of these changes are consistent with long-term warming and reduced ventilation of abyssal waters observed elsewhere in the world's oceans (almost certainly emanating from Antarctica)--a set of changes which could act to amplify and extend the long-term response of the ocean to greenhouse gas forcing by slowing the ocean's role as a heat sink and carbon storage reservoir.

Our specific identification of (a) the dense water pathways through the Samoan Passage and (b) the locations and dynamics responsible for mixing has important implications for the calculation of mixing in large-scale computer models which rely on accurate bottom water properties. Rather than a constant mixing rate, models of future circulation (which must simulate the global ocean for many decades or centuries and so cannot fully resolve the details of the Samoan Passage) will need to find a way to incorporate both the sensitivity of dense water pathways to bathymetric complexity such as multiple narrow passages and the response of mixing mechanisms along each pathway to the flow properties themselves. Our work suggests that large-scale simulations could incorporate simplified equations for the flow and mixing in the Samoan Passage (and other key abyssal locations) by combining a theory for pathway selection with mixing rates based on bottom roughness (following from the processes that we observed, including lee waves and hydraulic jumps). Progress in this direction will be continuing through a follow-on grant to combine our observational analysis with mathematical and computer models.

The impact of this work on the field of physical oceanography is in the improved understanding of both (i) the specific mechanisms of North Pacific bottom water transport and transformation and (ii) the general problem of topographic influence on weakly stratified gravity current flow. Also, as a case study in high-resolution sampling in space and time, our study demonstrated the power of combining profiling moorings and ship-based profilers to allow the separation of spatial and temporal variability in a complex environment.

Finally, outreach efforts performed under this grant (in Samoa and at science centers and schools in Seattle) helped broaden the understanding of the ocean and how physical processes (even in the abyss) influence ecosystems, climate, and human activity.
